Description: Pottery amphora, fragmentary, with painted decoration. On one side confronted boxers flank a prize dinos on a stand; a bird, probably a raptor, standing on an ionic column, survives behind one of the boxers. On the other side the heads of two standing women remain, behind whom are plants, a tree or a bush. Only one handle is present and the lower body is almost completely gone, together with the base. Around the neck of the vase is a band of four cartouches with the Throne Name and the Birth Name of the Egyptian king Apries of the Saite dynasty. Another large fragment, decorated with crescents and a scale pattern, belongs to the lower part of the same vessel but does no join.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Published and discussed (at pp. 59-66, fig. 31), with further literature, in Villing, A. 2021, ‘Between Apollo and Osiris: Egyptianising East Greek pottery, translating gods and cross-cultural interaction in the 6th century B.C.’, Jahrbuch des Deutschen Archäologischen Instituts 136, 1-110, https://doi.org/10.34780/6ca4-47c7
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2018 27 Mar-9 Sep, Los Angeles, Getty Centre, Egypt-Greece-Rome: Cultures in Contact
